status.changes:
<release version="2.3.0 (r76) date="28 March 2005">
Fixed the output of print_genotypes event. It was double-printing all historic genotypes with different formats (ick.)
Removed python files that are supposed to be autogenerated.
Removed obsolete python and pyuic files.
Moved AvidaED python files into source/python
Added scripts to build OS X application. AvidaED.app on OS X can be launched from command line for an interactive interpreter, or by double-clicking on its icon in the finder.
Fixed bad build rule prevent build of AvidaED/Mac.
AvidaED no longer starts an Avida Session at launch time. Instead an Avida object can be created after launch time using the sequence of commands (without semi-colons): avida = pyAvida(); avida.construct(genesis);
Added an AvidaED Xcode project for editing files.
Added pyuic build target to AvidaED Xcode project. Organized python files into sensible groups.
Fixed layout problems with OnePop_PetriDishView.
Added code to call routine to read freezer items.
Set pyPetriConfigureView to capture start signal.
Added code to write files into the freezer directory.
Added code to read default Genesis file, change values that have been modified by user in the PetriConfiguration screen, and write a new Genesis file into the working directory. Also copies the event, environment and organism file to working directory.
Added new reload commands for recently added classes.
Added signal support for the start button. Activated the start button.
Added signals to support freezing a populated petri dish. Added extractPopulationSlot to send all organisms in population to be frozen.
Added in sense instruction into hardware_cpu
Population graphing works again.
Added statistics code to support population information and actual graphing support.
Changed the look of various AvidaED windows.
Added a utility that will check all .ui files and find ones that are newer than their equivalent *.py files. The program will then offer the user the chance to create the .py file. User may need to change the command line to reflect the location of the pyuic program.
<release version="2.2.2 (r27) date="24 February 2005">
Added build instructions for third-party development software on OS X.
Clean up pyuic auto-generated files incorrectly being managed under source control. Updated Xcode project accordingly.
Incorporated speed ups posted by Dave MacLachlan on SourceForge and the DigitalEvolution mailing list.
Fixed Xcode project so that optimization settings are appropriately set according to build type. Added in additional optimizations suggested by Dave MacLachlan.
Fixed various pyste and build system components to handle various recent updates.
<release version="2.2.1 (r15) date="16 February 2005">
Allow code to compile on Linux with GCC version 3.4.
Modified bonus instructions to save and restore the previous execution state of the organism. Without this step, organisms could be prematurely marked as 'not running'. When combined with death, the objects could therefore be deleted twice. This would lead to stochastic memory corruption and crashes.
Initial Subversion Import
Added support for Forrest Documentation
Repair offspring merit calculation.
Minor modification to RECOMBINE comman in the analyze mode. A for loop was doing one less iteration that it shoud have resulting in creation of 2 less recombinant genomes.
Added another event, set_reaction_value_mult, that allows tou to multiply the reaction value, not just set it. Useful for changing environments setup. See documentation for more.
Windows release of latest updates for Discover Magazine article.
New CPU model, GUI components, and various research specific improvements.
Implemented proportional merit with sex...
Setup environment file with an extra command: SET_ACTIVE [type] [name] [active=true]
Type can currently only be "reaction" (but soon I'll also get resources working, and eventually mutations). Name is the name of the resource, and fitnally a true or false if you want that reaction turned on.
THEN I also added a command to the analyze mode called "ENVIRONMENT" which will allow you to add extra commands to define the environment file on the fly. For example, the analyze command:
ENVIRONMENT SET_ACTIVE reaction NOT false
Will turn off rewards for not. They can be turned back on again trivially with:
ENVIRONMENT SET_ACTIVE reaction NOT true
Made changes to arrays in analyze mode so that they use tArray and tMatrix to make them easier to use with variable sizes.
Added new functions "AnalyzeComplexity" and "AnalyzePopComplexity" to analyze source code.
Added in three new events to modify the topology of a population:
sever_column : sever a full column of cells
connect_cells : connect two cells together
disconnect_cells : disconnect two cells from each other.
Added some info about the new AVERAGE_MODULARITY analyze command to the documentation files.
After much tweaking, implemented a new analyze function, AVERAGE_MODULARITY.
Usage: AVERAGE_MODULARITY output_file task.0 task.1 task.2 task.3 task.4 task.5 task.6 task.7 task.8
Fixed the formula used to calculate Standard Error in various statistics parameters.
Widened number display fields in CPU viewer so that data can be read correctly.
Added buttons to select number format (binary, decimal, or hexadecimal) in Register, Inputs, and Stacks views of CPU viewer in GUI.
Minor bugfixes in 4-stack cpu parasite code.
Added option to count phenotypes based on tasks completed.
Workaround for bug in Qt/Windows: setInsideSpacing can't be safely called, so removed those calls.
Addition of CPU stats to instruction viewer in GUI.
Organism inputs are no longer per-cell, but per-organism; resolved related problem of request of now nonexistent inputs.
Restored missing initializations of subclass of cPopulationInterface class in qt-viewer.
Added documentation for some existing events. Changed some formatting of events.html documentation so file looks better with Safari web browser.
Added missing files to visual studio project.
Restored compatibility with older versions of gcc.
Added parasite tracking for 4-stack cpus, added events "print_dom_parasite" and "detail_parasite_pop", added default organsisms and settings for the 4-stack cpu.
Added Bounded Grid/Torus (world topology) switch to population. Leaving torus as the default.
Fixed some problems in mutation mapping in analyze mode.
Text viewer Zoom Screen Mini-Map fixed; Modified Map screen now in color; Thread Map screen now shows number of threads used by each organism.
Completion of 4 Stack Hardware. Inject command and parasite abilities now implemented. Text Viewer environment view mode in progress.
Added integer version WriteBlockElement to file output routines.
Correction of minor logical error in reaction handling.
Avida now runs and builds on Windows. Many minor changes were made for this, .pro files were added to be used with qmake, the way the configure script searches for the ncurses library was modified, pdcurses was incorporated instead of ncurses, trio was added to fix some string problems, and some very minor code changes were implemented to allow for some differences in the visual studio compiler.
new 4 stack hardware is implemented but not yet fully functional. It's compatible with primitive and ncurses modes, however will cause qt-viewer to crash if used. No functionality associated with the original hardware has been changed.
set up constant time slicer to skip over empty cells, this had been throwing an assert error in debug mode.
removed Visual Studio.net support files as they are out of date and no longer work properly.
introduced new 4 Stack CPU model. Removed 3 registers in CPU and replaced with 4 stacks. Added 4th NOP which allows use of all 4 stacks. Also changed complement system for nops. Pairs are now as follows: A,C; B,D; C,A; D,B;
newer C++ compilers want scoping on templates defined inside class definition, event if they are only used inside the class.
fixed problem with incorrect copying of instruction libraries when one instruction set was initialized to another one.
set up Avida to pring out a genesis file if none exists.
working on setting up Avida to generate an instruction set file in none exists. Attached 60 character or less descriptions to each of the default instructions, and attached a flag to all instructions declaring they are default.
added default event files in C++ that are generated from perl so Avida can be compiled in Windows without running perl script by hand as long as no new events are created or modified.
updated .pro files so don't have to change any properties in Visual Studio to compile
The hardware factory has always been creating CPU's of type cHardwareCPU even if everything else was assuming cHardware4Stack. This all works properly now.
added pdcurses.h and curses.lib to Avida so one doesn't have to actually check out the whole pdcurses suite to run on Windows.
added third party suite "Public Domain Curses" for Win32 compatability.
added event print_genotype_map that prints a Matlab file of the genotype IDs to a default file "genotype_map.m"
added empty directory aclocal to CVS so don't have to create it by hand every time build Avida from scratch
update .pri files for Windows builds
added Visual Studio.net support files for ncurses viewer, primitive mode, and qt-viewer.
cHardware4Stack now hooked into Avida and working properly
added new hardware type cHardware4Stack. Not hooked into rest of Avida yet...
re-engineered cFile class to work based off of arrays instead of linked lists. Each line is now stored as part of a structure which has other info associated with it, such as line numbers for better error reporting. Not being used yet, but available...
added HARDWARE_TYPE to genesis file and setup config to load it into Avida, it's not being used yet.
modified test_cup.cc to improve the default inputs in the test CPUs so they are more similar to those in the environment, and ideally give more accurate answers. Setup the default instruction set to be hooked in with a proper instruction library so that they can be used outside of a population (i.e. in analyze mode)
fixed bug in testCPU
changed cInstLib to cInstSet and cInstSuperLib to cInstLib. Renamed inst_lib.{cc,hh} to inst_set.{cc,hh} and inst_superlib.hh to inst_lib.hh. Updated other files accordingly to reflect this change
included instruction which injects a parasite into it's own thread. Also changed count.dat so that info regarding parasites is appended to the end of the file. Removed previous parasite info which is now obsolete.
edited Makefile.am to reflect the fact that built event source file depends are build-tree relative but cpu source file depends are source-tree relative
removed unused sourcecode from beneath qt subdirectory
introduced cInstSuperLib to contain a complete library of available instructions corresponding to a given hardware class. cInstLib now indexes into arrays provided by cInstSuperLib
mkdir() is not defined in win32 so added win32_mkdir_hack.hh to define it as a macro so can use in windows version
modified namespaces, adding 'using namespace std' appropriately throughout Avida to allow compilation on Windows
set up qt builds to be performed using qmake on seperately maintained .pro files
fixed error in new tasks, now cast int to double before taking log
added code to allow spatial resources
allow long lines in an input file to be split across multiple physical lines by use of a \ character at the end of the line as a continuation marker
added two routines to aid the printing of spatial resource data: writeblock - allows for the output of individual grid points writeraw - allows any line to be written anywhere in an output file
added event kill_rectangle which allows user to kill all organisms in a rectangle described by points (X1, Y1) and (X2, Y2).
no longer crashes when population dies out.
added version of Max function with type double. added function Neighbor that works with population and spatial resource arrays to find the current neighboring cells (even at edge of matrix).
fixed time slicer problem where drastic drop in maximum merit would slow down a run considerably. Added warning when analyze mode tries to load in a string sequence thats supposed to represent a genome, but maximum char goes beyond instruction set size.
previous runs can no longer be replicated even when a random seed used is known due to extensive reorganization of portions of code that handle divides.
initial implementation of sex. Now exists divide-sex and divide-asex commands, former facilitating recombination between two offspring by swapping a region of their code.
fixed hardware getting incorrect info as to if it lived through birth process.
removed mutation rate drifting options and old style crossovers.
assembled framework for sexual divides. Mostly involved pushing some of the final offspring creation to the population and out of the organism.
Avida has been almost entirely rewritten.
Fixed a problem with CHILD_SIZE_RANGE in the genesis file -- it used to only compare the child size to the *new* parent size; now it will properly compare it to the original parent size (and make sure that the new parent size also falls into the same legal range)
Added an Average Fitness output in the primitive viewer.
Added a column 10 to the stats.dat output file that indicates the depth of the most recent coalescent genotype.
Removed "defs.hh" dependency from assert; stay out of debug move by default -- only enter it when DEBUG is defined.
Rebuilt data_file.??, simplifying the internal structure and using a proper linked list. Also removed dependency on defs.hh.
Removed dependencies in string.?? ; fixed some bugs in Compare() that didn't turn up before, but seem real. Often '\0' was being saught when a cString was being compared to a char *, when the cString data does not end in a \0 (a seperate size measure is kept)
Removed global memory object. It was used throughout the code, but most allocations did *not* make use of it. We should use some kind of solid memory tracking method, but this one was less than optimal.
In the viewer, shifted the maps from being normal arrays to using the tArray object; also kept them all local to maps (rather than being allocated in one place and freed in another like they were)
Shifted environment connection lists such that they are now part of the environment from the beginning and only initialize (not created) by the population. Plus some general cleanup and organization in them.
Moved all cList objectes over to the cleaner, templated tList. This allowed for some standardization in our current way of doing things, a cleaner interface (and simplification of some code). In the future we may want to move all of this over to the STL list template, but for the moment this was much easier.
Cut down on the number of includes from tools.hh; most of them are not required.
Converted all of the "TRUE" and "FALSE" occurances to "true" and "false" throughout the entire code. Changed int to bool in most appropriate cases.
Moved code_array.?? entirely over to assert from debug.
Anihilated old geneology stuff.
Went through header files in source/main/ and removed all non-required includes.
Removed the very old [5+ years] resources implementation.
Removed everything to do with redcode.
Removed Block time slicer.
Abstracted out the time slicer so it just keeps a collection of ints, each with their own merit, and a "GetNextID()" method which returns the int that goes next... Moved both slice and merit into the tools directory.
Adjusted the header files in the viewer so that the viewer takes virtually no time to compile in primitive mode.
Added BENCHMARK file to keep track of timings of avida as changes are made. Added MAP file to track #include's. Add tMemTrack for potential tracking.
Removed files:
source/cpu/cpu.ii source/cpu/hardware.ii source/cpu/head.ii source/cpu/interface.cc source/cpu/interface.hh source/main/classes.hh source/main/geneology.cc source/main/geneology.hh source/tools/include.hh source/tools/lookup.cc source/tools/lookup.hh source/tools/memory.cc source/tools/memory.hh source/tools/memory.ii source/tools/memtrack.cc source/tools/memtrack.hh source/tools/struct.cc source/tools/struct.hh
Moved functionality from inst_lib.hh into its code file...
Removed cFlags object entirely; got rid of tools.ii.
Removed debug.ii, random.ii, and string.ii
Created a string_util.?? component to hold higher level string methods.
Created a seperate inst_args.?? component to contain instructions that can have arguments. Ideally this needs to be further compartmentalized in the futures.
Created cGenome and cCPUMemory to replace cCodeArray; a *much* cleaner interface. They are in main/genome.?? and cpu/cpu_memory.?? respectively. [This was a very serious, code-wide change!] cGenome is a fixed length, doesn't have flags associated with each instruction, and is used for most of the old occurances of cCodeArray. cCPUMemory is more similar to the original cCodeArray, but is derived from cGenome (henece functions that that cGenome can use either) and has many fewer methods that should add up to the same functionality.
Added main/genome_util.?? for static genome manipulation and comparison functions (like Hamming and Edit distances).
Stripped out a lot of the redundent methods from cHardware. More of this should be done.
Moved tracking of stepping through organisms in the viewer over to population. Got rid of all of the AltInstructionSet nonsense that used to handle it. There are now two tight loops in DoUpdate() ; one of them is run if you're stepping, the other if your not, so there should be no speed loss.
Continued to stip down the interface to cHardware. Ideally we'll be able to shift instruction execution in there soon (from cBaseCPU) and rebuild cBaseCPU into cOrganism or somesuch.
Re-vamped cInstLib. Made cInstEntry a private object, and generally cleaned up the insides. Inst libs might take longer to load at startup now (insignificant since its done only once, and we're talking miliseconds), but the interface is *much* cleaner.
Created seperate inst_util.?? component to handle interations between inst_lib and genomes (such as printing) and initializations of inst libraries.
Got rid of arg-based instruction set and binary instruction set entirely. This had remarkably far-reaching effects.
Removed curses.?? [Its old enough that we shouldn't need it anymore, and the interface was out of date.]
Created a tDictionary template that takes in strings with arbitrary data, and can lookup the data via the string. Uses a hast table keyed off of the string.
Avida will now warn you if you attempt to load an instruction in the inst library that doesn't exits. It used to just ignore it.
Merged cCreature into cBaseCPU. Removed creature.hh
Moved cCPUStack into its own component
Separated out hardware and cpu into logical elements. This is a huge change, and I'm not going into detail here about it.
Setup memory allocation method Necrophelia to work more correctly -- it now uses the older memory that was lingering in the hardware the organism is in.
Shifted cpu/cpu.?? to main/organism.?? and cleaned up dependencies.
In genesis, changed the name of the RESET_* configuration variables, to the more acurate STERILIZE_*
Added #include <string.h> in string.hh and debug.hh -- it was crashing on calls to strlen() on some newer compilers.
Fixed templates in tDictionary; reuse of "T" as templated class crashed on some newer compilers.
Fixed make_events.pl -- it was creating statments in the form of (test_input == "") variable=default : variable=input_value; This is a problem since the variable should always be on the outside of such statements. Unfortunatly, that gives other errors, so I changed it to a proper if-else. New format is: if (test_input == "") variable=default; else variable=input_value;
Fixed some const problems in events.
Added genesis option "REQUIRED_TASK", which lets the user set the id of a mandatory task for a divide to be successful.
Removed the cAvidaMain events files. All events are now defined in events/cPopulation.events. I removed two events completely, the one to change the viewer and the one to print the event list. I think both are pretty unnecessary (and are in the way of cleaning up the code more).
Removed LINEAR_MEMORY option...
Systematically shifted some includes to be more restrictive (in .cc rather than .hh)
Removed class cCPUInfo entirely; placed most components into cPhenotype, and the rest directly into cOrganism.
Created hardware_util.?? to handle loading of hardware methods into instruction libraries.
Created lineage_util.?? to remove lineage printing (and hence all knowledge of lineages) from stats.
Created organism_util.?? to provide a location for functions that act on organisms but require the use of both genotype and genebank.
Lots of changes throughout viewer to get it up and running again with all the modifications from the rest of the code...
Added more descriptive faults in the zoom mode of the viewer; helpful in debugging organism operation.
Changed minimum executed and copied size so that at the minimum values, the organisms are legal, but not below (changed a '<=' to just a '<'). This means that with a minimum copied size of 1.0, everything must be copied (as opposed to more than everything, which was causing this to break before.
Generally did a lot of prep work to get the organisms well seperated from the population... That'll be the next big step.
Created a population_cell.?? component; populations have a collection of cells instead of organisms -- the cells contain the organisms that make up the population.
Created a seperate mutations.?? component, with a cMutationRates class to keep track of mutation rates, and handle basic functions dealing with them. Each population cell has its own mutaiton rates, which get passed to any organism placed into that cell. All traces of mutations have been removed from environments.
Most of the system has been fully levelized -- all of the files in the tools/ main/ and cpu/ directories are set; only the viewer and events are left to be done, and they should be rather straigh-forward. Take a look at current/source/tools/MAP and current/source/LEVELS for more info.
Organisms are now unique entities for their entire existance; they used to be referred to as CPUs in the code, and would have new genomes regularly loaded into them. A population is now a collection of cells, each of which can be occupied with an organism or not. When an organism gives birth, it passes a fully constructed offspring organism to the population to be placed.
The population object itself has been entirely overhauled. Its streamlined to now have a minimal number of methods, including the key methods ActivateOrganism(), which is always called to place an organism in a population, and KillOrganism() which must be called to remove an organism. This allows central points for statistics to be done, though they haven't been moved there yet.
Hardware construction and destruction has been centralized in a hardware factory object; this will allow recycling of hardware objects for a speed increase, though this optimization still needs to be finished.
A number of utility classes have been created to more complex manipulation of objects that don't belong inside of them. This has made the relevent classes cleaner and easier to understand.
Added configure mode --enable-normal to compile without either debug or optimization. Much faster for testing!
Major re-engineering of cPhenotype -- the internals should be much cleaner now.
Created symbol_util.?? component in viewers to remove all of the symbol handling from population_cell.??
Got TestCPUs working properly at last.
Got death working again.
Tracing now provides registers in both decimal and hex formats. Also, merit is broken down into initial (either constant or proportional to length) and earned bonuses.
Removed a bunch of viewer related methods from cAvidaMain that were either unused or redundant.
Cleaned up even more header files (in particular test_cpus were being included in some components they didn't need to be in any more.)
The GetTest[...] methods in genotype had had some problems when a genotype wasn't viable; these should be fixed now.
Surpressed output of warning that data files are bring over-written. Ideally, we'll put this back in properly at some point, but at the moment, its messes with the viewer.
Improved output methods, and in particular "species.dat" for speciation measurements.
Moved task_buffer.?? to the more generic template tBuffer.hh and placed it in tools.
Removed all portions of current resource system throughout code (in preperation of setting up a new one).
Renamed event_list to events.cfg
Changed all "special" assert commands to the default assert.
Moved inst_lib and mutation rates into environment.
Repaired generation counting... it was always incrementing the generation of parent no matter what the genesis file said, and *then* it would increment the generation of the parent. Obviously this was a bug all around and its now fixed. I did, however, set the defaults to splitting and increasing the generation of both parent and child.
Many new features, see info for details.
Added events and other features.
Fixed ncurses under RedHat Linux 6.x, as well as other bugs.
Fixed ncurses under RedHat Linux 5.x.

actions.action: Setup CMake to build application bundle.
Move python subdir out of Boost.Python subdir.
Add python unit test to dashboards.
